sub_title: Graduate MSc Cultural and Social Anthropology & MSc International Development Studies | PR & Communications Officer at the Equal Trade Alliance | Youth Ambassador at the ONE Campaign
summary:
I am a cultural anthropologist with a preference for a human-centered, decolonial and intersectional approach to the promotion of social, political and economic justice. As an anthropologist, I think I am very much aware of how oppressive systems such as racism, sexism or classism imbricate and intersect with each other creating structural, multifaceted and varietgated forms of (group-based) oppression and privilege. My interest in international development studies has taught me how the micro, meso and macro level are interconnected in the reproduction but also contestation of oppressive systems such as neoliberal capitalism, white supremacy/Western neocolonialist hegemony and the Anthropocene. By corollary, the personal is political and collective action is key to social change.

My primary goal in life is to be an amplifier agent for grassroots movements advocating for self-liberation from oppressive systems premised on progressive imaginaries of (incremental) system change in addition to institutional change. Since I was 13 years old, I have been volunteering in various roles to acquire experience in activism, policy advice, research, project proposal writing, campaigning, lobbying, raising the awareness of the general public, applying for funds, and event management. Overall, I am very passionate about essentially every cause related to social, political and economic justice. This for me is a lifelong commitment to what I think is the right thing to do. In all my endeavors, I always intend to use my privileges to contribute to a world with radical empathy, equity and inclusivity. By the same token, I always try to decenter myself when appropriate to give latitude for manouevre to those who possess lived experience in facing the repercussions of oppressive systems.

certifications.name: Global Volunteer
certifications.authority: AIESEC in Bahrain - AIESEC في البحرين

company.name: AIESEC in Bahrain - AIESEC في البحرين

profile_positions.description:
The Equal Trade Alliance is a research, advocacy and lobbying forum active in more than 40 European and African countries for the institutionalization of Equal Trade Certification.This certification scheme oriented towards the decolonization of trade relations would effectuate an equitable redistribution of profits and revenues generated throughout the value chains of primary commodities. If implemented, Equal Trade could contribute to the dismantlement of modern slavery, the termination of labour exploitation, the prevention and resolution of resource conflicts, disincentivizing corruption, and the mitigation and adaptation to climate change on the African continent amongst other things. Repatriating a substantially higher percentage of profit could be used for productive reinvestment in domestic industries, sectors and companies to buttress the capacity for economic self-sufficiency and thus support economic sovereignty. Also it would allow for more public expenditure on government services such as healthcare, social security programs, income support, and education.

My primary task is communicating the mission of the ETA by written word to different audiences such as politicians, lobbyists, NGO professionals, activists, academics, students and corporate actors. To support this primary objective, I am responsible for writing project proposals and funding requests.
profile_positions.title: Project Proposal Writer & PR and Communications Officer
Advisor Africa Day Youth Think Tank for Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs

profile_positions.description:
The ONE Campaign is part of an advocacy organization for the eradication of extreme poverty and preventable diseases by 2030. It is a global organization spanning Africa, Europe and North-America. Its mission is to amplify the development priorities and needs identified by African leaders, activists, advocates, and development professionals. Its methodology entails research, policy recommendations, consultations with African stakeholders, petitioning and lobbying governments in Africa, Europe and North America.

As youth ambassadors, we are responsible for lobbying politicians in our own countries (i.e. the Netherlands) to take into account the ONE its campaigns with respect to for instance climate adaptation finance, increasing ODA budget and reforming multilateral development banks. On top of that, it is our responsibility to spread awareness to the wider public on the development challenges facing our world by providing information at educational and non-educational events. Additionally, we ask the wider public to sign our petitions related to our causes in order to submit these to the Dutch government.
profile_positions.title: Youth Ambassador
Defender (Campaigning Commission in the role of integrator)

profile_positions.description:
I have been selected as a student for ActionAid Nederland's Climate Justice School, which spans a period of four months.

In the first stage, we will learn about the relationship between climate justice and women’s rights through interactive workshops, seminars and meet&greets with various academics, lobbyists, government officials, politicians, activists and actors affiliated with NGOs.

In the second stage, we will create our own initiative for COP27 to advocate for gender just climate action from lawmakers, policy makers, politicians and government officials.
profile_positions.title: Climate Justice Student & Activist

profile_positions.description: As a cultural anthropologist, I write commentaries on issues related to social justice. I incorporate my own reflection, analysis and opinion into my essays. The deficiencies in the implementation of pan-Africanism in the African Union and systemic change for ecological sustainability are examples of issues I write about.
profile_positions.title: Blogger

profile_positions.description:
For Syrian Volunteers in the Netherlands, I conducted ethnographic research encompassing primary and secondary data analysis for an advisory policy report for the municipality of Amsterdam.

In the period of July 2020 till October 2020, we were conducting research in a team for the purpose of policy changes at the municipal level. Such policy changes were intended to allow migrant doctors to be professionally involved in the field of healthcare as an auxiliary apprentice under the supervision of a Dutch physician for example. During the COVID-19 pandemic, there were personnel shortages in the health care sector, which would ideally be supplemented by tremendously motivated migrant doctors whom are barred from practicing medicine due to a restrictive bureaucratic and inefficient rule-based system.
profile_positions.title: Ethnographic Researcher

profile_positions.description:
For the labour union, I have been active for this campaign, Voor14, which advocated for a higher minimum wage to alleviate poverty in The Netherlands among the working poor.

It was my task to mobilize as many people as possible by encouraging people to sign the petition for a higher minimum wage. I did so by distributing leaflets elucidating the necessity of a higher minimum wage. Think about not having insufficient financial resources to travel to your city center by public transport or not having a warm meal everyday.
profile_positions.title: Campaigner

volunteer_experiences.role: Project Proposal Writer & PR and Communications Officer

volunteer_experiences.role: Defender (Campaigning Commission in the role of integrator)

volunteer_experiences.description:
I have been selected as a student for ActionAid Nederland's Climate Justice School, which spans a period of four months.

In the first stage, we will learn about the relationship between climate justice and women’s rights through interactive workshops, seminars and meet&greets with various academics, lobbyists, government officials, politicians, activists and actors affiliated with NGOs.

In the second stage, we will create our own initiative for COP27 to advocate for gender just climate action from lawmakers, policy makers, politicians and government officials.

In a team of highly motivated LGBTQI+'ers and allies we subscribe to this mandate of eliminating all forms of (physical) violence and discrimination. We are non-hierarchical and inclusive towards everybody by virtue of our intersectional approach.

We do so by:
- Attending solidarity manifestations and protests related to injustices plaguing the LGBTQI+ community
- Broadcasting our own End H.A.T.E podcast on Spotify
- Organizing events like panel discussions on LGBTQI+ issues curtailing the physical and psychological integrity of LGBTQI+'ers

I've been assigned to the position of co-manager to coordinate the event by sending invitations to speakers, to formulate questions for our speakers that will be discussed during the events and to debrief our speakers.

For Syrian Volunteers in the Netherlands, I conducted ethnographic research encompassing primary and secondary data analysis for an advisory policy report for the municipality of Amsterdam. 

In the period of July 2020 till October 2020, we were conducting research in a team for the purpose of policy changes at the municipal level. Such policy changes were intended to allow migrant doctors to be professionally involved in the field of healthcare as an auxiliary apprentice under the supervision of a Dutch physician for example. During the COVID-19 pandemic, there were personnel shortages in the health care sector, which would ideally be supplemented by tremendously motivated migrant doctors whom are barred from practicing medicine due to a restrictive bureaucratic and inefficient rule-based system.

For the labour union I was active for this campaign Voor14, which advocates for a higher minimum wage to alleviate poverty in The Netherlands among the working poor.

It was my task to mobilize as many people as possible by encouraging people to sign the petition for a higher minimum wage. I did so by distributing leaflets that clarified the necessity for a higher minimum wage. Think about not having insufficient saldo to travel to your city center by public transport or not having a warm meal everyday.

Together with my student team, we are engaging with human rights. We organize educational events on human rights violations in The Netherlands and abroad. For this purpose, we utilize our networks to find academic and activist speakers and to accommodate their messages within a place made safe for sharing.

Furthermore, we attend solidarity manifestations and protest on behalf of our Amnesty International student team and we collect petitions to acquit human rights activists and to recuperate their divested liberties and rights.

In collaboration with my fellow volunteers, we help to bridge the mild language barriers of children from predominantly Dutch-Arabic backgrounds. In a playful manner, we focus on reading and speaking skills by means of spelling tests, reading texts, debating and creative writing. Our get together is standardly on a Thursday afternoon each week.

Each year in July, we have got an outing to the beach, a lake or an island for example. It's our responsibility as volunteers to safeguard the childrens' safety and to entertain them in a playful manner.

volunteer_experiences.role: Fund requester for undocumented refugees (widows, orphans and single mothers)
volunteer_experiences.description:
In this position I worked alone. It was my responsibility to sollicit funds from charity organizations that would enable mothers and children to live more freely and financially secure. An arrangement for free diapers or membership to a sports club  would for example alleviate somewhat of the pressure that is accompanied by being undocumented, marginalized and socio-economically underprivileged.

Besides my function as a fund requester, I was also regularly asked to write letters to migration lawyers or to call general practitioners for medical appointments. Also, I helped undocumented refugees with finding a place to sleep at night by contacting relevant charity organizations. On top of that, I printed walking routes for people who wanted to visit their lawyers for instance but could not connect to 4G or could not travel by public transport.

volunteer_experiences.role: Guest teacher in program concerning climate change affecting China and the Netherlands
volunteer_experiences.description:
Alongside a Chinese interpreter, I have been privileged to teach about climate change (perpetrated by the corporate industry) in The Netherlands and to learn about the Chinese initiatives to mitigate the repercussions of climate change. The project took place on a Chinese primary school. The children we taught were 11 and 12. 

Initially, it was my intention to set up a dialogue between the children, my interpreter and me, but my interpreter shortly told me how Chinese children are not particularly accustomed to a more egalitarian modality of teaching such as in The Netherlands. She taught me how Chinese culture is more hierarchical and reverent towards authority than Dutch culture. Hence, it became more of a teacher-student methodology to impart the severity of climate change on students' conscience. This required some intercultural sensitivity and competence.

We talked about the culpability of corporations with concerns to climate change considering their profit-oriented business models aiming at maximum productivity. Also, we taught about the impact of climate change on biodiversity, ecosystems, (indigenous and poor) communities, (low-income) countries and the world.  

When the children felt more comfortable with us, I asked them for their input on what they could do to counteract climate change. Then we started learning from each other about the methods one can employ as an individual to diminish one's ecological footprint. 

What's more, we engaged in fun games impersonating animals threatened by climate change for example. Additionally, I learned about a garbage separation plan the local authorities were implementing a month later at the time. Me and my interpreterer therefore came up with fun games to make children more familiar with this mode of garbage separation. It was a wonderful experience and the children were very smart!

volunteer_experiences.role: Participant in cross-cultural teaching project concerning Dutch and Brazilian forms of identity-based oppressions and privileges
volunteer_experiences.description:
At Colégio Ypiranga, a high school in Salvador, we worked in guest teacher teams consisting of Portuguese language interpreters and volunteers from abroad. We made the format of our teaching program very interactive in order to open up a dialogue. Our students were made interlocutors in a cross-cultural comparison of the structural violence precipitated by colonialism, enslavement and white supremacy. We listened to the experiences of our students with racism, colourism, classism, LGBTQI+-phobia, misogyny and sexism as the violent implications of Brazil's history of colonialism and enslavement.  

Subsequently, we tried to show how the structure of white supremacy for instance is a universal phenomenon given the expansionist agenda of historical colonizers. We talked about the knowledge we have on our countries violent pasts and the contemporary ramifications affecting the oppressed. 

In the final stage of the project, we thought about little things you can do to address forms of oppression, to protect each other and to come together to spread a counter-narrative. In addition, we focussed on anti-bullying efforts against colourism or homophobia for instance. 

All in all, we did not only teach, but we also learned a lot about how to navigate your own privileges, how to listen to different perspectives, how to identify cross-cultural patterns and how to determine intersections.

Present-day, I am still in contact with some students of mine. Through WhatsApp and FaceTime I assist them with their English homework assignments. Also, we still discuss forms of oppression and the methods we can use together to combat it.

At primary school SDN-3 Gondangdia Pagi in Jakarta, I was a guest teacher catering to one class of thirty children for six weeks. In a playful manner, we explored the English language by first establishing their level of English, their proficiency and vocabulary. Working on that as a base, me and my interpreter decided on themes for each week such as family, cultural differences and similarities between Indonesia and the Netherlands, and career dreams. Together with my interpreter we taught English classes. Prior to the start of the lessons, we often practiced our presentation to facilitate teamwork.

In addition, we organized a craft project at the primary school at which we had taught. Afterwards, we sold the handicrafts made by our students for a small price to pedestrians, who were interested in the stands we made to showcase our national culture. Eventally, the money that had been collected was donated to two local founders of an orphanage, who wanted to invest in a renovation project for the classrooms.

Last but not least, I organized a couple of auxiliary lessons for high school girls in my neighbourhood, who had requested English tutoring. A couple of times the girls came to me, so I could assist them with their homework. In these tutor sessions, I spoke in elementary Indonesian to communicate with them and they would try to speak English with me. I helped them with exercises and assignments. 

Sidenote: I still teach them through digital platforms like WhatsApp and Facetime. Also my pool of students has slightly expanded itself. I am still occasionally assisting high school and primary school children with their homework at the moment.

volunteer_experiences.role: Assistant of an English language teacher at Kayan, a special education school in Bahrain
volunteer_experiences.description: In 2017, I attended a project in which I assisted an English teacher, who taught mentally and/or physically disabled children in the age category of 4-6. I had to sort out and study the teaching material to co-teach under the auspices of an English teacher at Kayan, a special education school in Manama, Bahrain. It was also required of me to think of and enact creative teaching methods like dance choreographies, songs and games for the children. Occasionally, I needed to feed children who were physically disabled.

volunteer_experiences.role: Awareness raiser on sexual diversity and gender diveristy
volunteer_experiences.description: Within a team structure, we founded a GayStraightAlliance to be operational at Zaanlands Lyceum, Zaandam (high school). We brainstormed on ideas to make the high school environment more LGBTQI+-friendly and advocated for these ideas to be implemented by the administrative body of our high school. We held presentations offering additional teaching material concerning topics involving the LGBTQI+-community. We organized Purple Friday, an annual day that entirely revolves around LGBTQI+ awareness raising, the importance of anti-bullying and solidarity through fun activities. Lastly, we attended national GSA conferences for LGBTQI+ high school students and their straight, cisgender allies to share ideas and discuss progress in terms of awareness and acceptance of sexual diversity and gender diveristy.

OurLifeProject has been a project in which ten brave young women spoke up about prevalent problems among youth which are considered taboo topics. Examples would be mental health problems, domestic violence, sexual assault and rape, and bullying. I have been honoured to assist the girls and founders of the project for the organization and execution of an event intended to break taboo topics and to remedy the loneliness that inevitably is bound to being silent on these topics. Many people turned up and shared their stories. 

Finally, we recorded a video in which I acted as an experience expert on these taboo topics. I shared my story and my tips and tricks for self-empowerment, opening up to others and recovery. The video was intended to show people in similar positions that they were not alone and could contact us if they wanted to talk about it.

This project is an annually recurring week filled by recreational activities for children from socio-economically disadvantaged backgrounds. Holidays are a luxury good which their parents cannot afford unfortunately. For this reason over a hundred volunteers commit themselves to giving these children an experience similar to a holiday. The week itself is filled with games, sports, outings and parties. In a team, we supervised the childrens' safety, played with them and entertained them.

skills: Translating idealistic visions into concrete plans
Building metaphorical bridges between different groups of people
